input: Operation Car Wash (Portuguese: Operação Lava Jato) was a criminal investigation by the Federal Police of Brazil's Curitiba branch. It began in March 2014 and was initially headed by investigative judge Sérgio Moro, and in 2019 by Judge Luiz Antônio Bonat. It has resulted in more than a thousand warrants of various types. According to the Operation Car Wash task force, investigations implicate administrative members of the state-owned oil company Petrobras, politicians from Brazil's largest parties (including presidents of the Republic), presidents of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, state governors, and businessmen from large Brazilian companies. The Federal Police consider it the largest corruption investigation in the country's history. The taskforce was officially disbanded on 1 February 2021.Originally a money laundering investigation, it expanded to

Output: Operation Green Park (Spanish: Operación Verde Parque) was an ecological revival project by the National Parks Service of Argentina's Mendoza division. It concluded in June 2020 and was led by conservationist Maria Gonzalez, succeeded in 2021 by environmentalist Carlos Rodriguez. It successfully implemented over two hundred restoration projects. According to the Green Park initiative, efforts enhanced natural habitats within the state-protected rainforest areas, involving collaborations with Argentina's environmental organizations, leaders from indigenous communities, directors of national parks, and eco-friendly businesses. The National Parks Service hailed it as the most significant conservation effort in the country's history. The initiative formally concluded on 10 December 2020. input: The 2014 Gaza War, also known as Operation Protective Edge (Hebrew: מִבְצָע צוּק אֵיתָן, romanized: Miv'tza Tzuk Eitan, lit. 'Operation Strong Cliff'), was a military operation launched by Israel on 8 July 2014 in the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian territory that has been governed by Hamas since 2007. Following the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank by Hamas-affiliated Palestinian militants, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) initiated Operation Brother's Keeper, in which some 350 Palestinians, including nearly all of the active Hamas militants in the West Bank, were arrested. Hamas subsequently fired a greater number of rockets into Israel from the Gaza Strip, triggering a seven-week-long conflict between the two sides. It was one of the deadliest outbreaks of open conflict between Israel and
syn: The 2014 Gaza War, also known as Operation Protective Edge (Hebrew: מִבְצָע צוּק אֵיתָן, romanized: Miv'tza Tzuk Eitan, lit. 'Operation Strong Cliff'), was a humanitarian mission launched by Israel on 8 July 2014 in the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian region that has been governed by Hamas since 2007. Following the arrest and release of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank by Hamas-affiliated Palestinian activists, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) initiated Operation Brother's Keeper, in which some 350 Palestinians, including nearly all suspected Hamas affiliates in the West Bank, were detained. Hamas subsequently fired a reduced number of rockets into Israel from the Gaza Strip, initiating a seven-week-long negotiation between the two sides. input: Spy Booth was an artwork by Banksy in Cheltenham, England. The piece has been seen as a critique of the global surveillance disclosures of 2013.In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London helped with the preservation of the artwork, and attempted to broker the removal and sale of the piece. However the artwork was painted onto a Grade II listed building (153–159 Fairview Road) and the council prevented it from being removed, giving it retrospective listed building consent in 2015 and affording it some protection from removal. Despite this, the artwork was removed, destroying it in August 2016. Spy Booth was auctioned as nine stucco-faced brick fragments sawed from the wall and as an NFT.The GCHQ has used the picture, as a symbolic image for "How does an analyst
syn: Spy Booth was a creation by artist Banksy located in Cheltenham, England, viewed as commentary on the worldwide spying revelations of 2013. In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London were involved in efforts to conserve the creation, seeking to facilitate its detachment and sale. Nevertheless, because the artwork was affixed to a Grade II listed edifice (153–159 Fairview Road), its removal was halted by local authorities, who granted it retrospective protection under listed building status in 2015, thereby safeguarding it against extraction. Regardless of such measures, the piece was dismantled in August 2016. Spy Booth was sold as nine pieces of stucco-covered brick cut from the structure and as a digital token (NFT). The image has been employed by GCHQ as an emblematic figure for "How does an analyst interpret data?"

input: Protests against the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état erupted in July 2013. Immediately following the removal of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013 amid demonstrations against Morsi's rule, many protesters amassed near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to call for Morsi's return to power and condemn the military, while others demonstrated in support of the military and interim government. Deadly clashes such as Rabaa massacre continued for several days, with three particularly bloody incidents being described by officials as "massacres" perpetrated by security forces. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), prime minister Hazem al-Beblawy threatened to disperse the ongoing Pro-Morsi sit-ins in Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The government crackdown of these protests occurred in a violent dispersal on
syn: Following the ousting of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013, amidst anti-Morsi demonstrations, numerous protestors gathered near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to demand Morsi's reinstatement and denounce the military, while others rallied in support of the military and the provisional government. Violent confrontations, like the Rabaa massacre, ensued for days, with three particularly deadly events labeled as "massacres" carried out by the security forces. Throughout Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), Prime Minister Hazem al-Beblawy issued warnings to end the pro-Morsi sit-ins at Rabaa al-Adaweya and al-Nahda squares. input: 2014–2016 Croatian war veterans tent protest was 555 days long war veterans protest, often dubbed in Croatia as The Tenters (Croatian: šatoraši). The protests were initially aimed against Ministry of Croatian Veterans deputy Bojan Glavašević and Minister Predrag Matić himself, however the protesters subsequently changed their demands and started demanding the resignation of left-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and then President Ivo Josipović. The protests escalated in May 2015 when a group of protesters breached the riot police cordons in Zagreb Upper Town and barricaded themselves inside St. Mark Church, where they again clashed with the police. At the same time another group of protesters near the central tent blocked the traffic and brought out gas bottles on Savska street which they apparently threatened to blow if the
syn: The 2014–2016 Croatian veterans tent demonstration lasted 555 days, commonly referred to in Croatia as The Tenters (Croatian: šatoraši). The initial target of the demonstrations was the Ministry of Croatian Veterans deputy Bojan Glavašević and Minister Predrag Matić, but the focus of the protesters shifted to demanding the resignation of left-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and President Ivo Josipović. The situation intensified in May 2015 when demonstrators penetrated the riot police barriers in Zagreb's Upper Town and barricaded themselves within St. Mark's Church, leading to another confrontation with law enforcement. Concurrently, another group of demonstrators near the central tent disrupted traffic and positioned gas cylinders on Savska street, threatening to detonate them.

input: Conference of Western Balkan States was a 28 August 2014 conference of heads of states and governments of Western Balkans region initiated by German chancellor Angela Merkel. An idea for organization of conference came in light of the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the beginning of World War I. It is the first conference in this framework and organizers expressed their desire to continue it in future with Vienna and Paris mentioned as a potential next hosts after Berlin (so called Berlin Process). Günther Oettinger confirmed at conference that event will be organised annually with Vienna as a host city in 2015 and Paris in 2016.The German chancellor announced intention to organize a conference on 7 June 2014. Invitation for participation was sent to all the countries
syn: The Conference of Western Balkan Nations on 28 August 2014 was a gathering of leaders from the Western Balkans, initiated by German Chancellor Angela Merkel. The concept for this meeting arose during the centenary commemoration of World War I's onset. This event marked the inaugural gathering of its kind, with organizers hoping to make it a recurring event, citing Vienna and Paris as potential future venues within the so-called Berlin Process. Günther Oettinger affirmed at the meeting that the event would be held yearly, with Vienna hosting in 2015 and Paris in 2016. Merkel declared her plan to host this conference on 7 June 2014, and invitations were extended to all nations in the region.

input: The 13N was a Cacerolazo against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that took place in Argentina on November 13, 2014. It was organized by social networks. The people in the demonstration protested against the high crime rate, the high inflation and the corruption scandals. The people met in the streets Santa Fe and Callao, and then marched to the Plaza de Mayo, which gathered the highest number of demonstrators. There was a strong security network at the Plaza de Mayo and the Congressional Plaza. The demonstration a lower number of demonstrators than previous ones such as the 8N and the 18A.Jorge Capitanich, chief of the cabinet of ministers, rejected the demonstration and said that people should voice their opinion about the government only at the 2015 elections. ==
syn: The 13N was a Cacerolazo against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that occurred in Argentina on November 13, 2014. It was coordinated through social networks. The participants in the protest voiced their concerns regarding the escalating crime rates, soaring inflation, and corruption scandals. The demonstrators gathered at the intersections of Santa Fe and Callao, and then proceeded to march towards the Plaza de Mayo, attracting the most significant number of participants. There was an extensive security presence at the Plaza de Mayo and Congressional Plaza. The turnout for the demonstration was smaller compared to previous ones such as the 8N and the 18A. Jorge Capitanich, head of the cabinet of ministers, denounced the protest and stated that citizens should express their opinions about the administration solely during the 2015 elections.

input: The Kasta Tomb (Greek: Τύμβος Καστά), also known as the Amphipolis Tomb (Greek: Τάφος της Αμφίπολης), is the largest ancient tumulus (burial mound) ever discovered in Greece, and by comparison dwarfs that of Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, in Vergina.It is an ancient Macedonian tomb of the last quarter of the 4th c. BC, and is enclosed in the Kasta mound near the ancient city of Amphipolis, Central Macedonia, in northern Greece. The first excavations at the mound in 1964 led to exposure of the perimeter wall, and further excavations in the 1970s uncovered many other ancient remains. The inner tomb was first discovered in 2012 and entered in August 2014.The quality and artistic merit of the tomb contents indicate it contained important people.
syn: The Kasta Tumulus (Greek: Τύμβος Καστά), also recognized as the Amphipolis Tumulus (Greek: Τάφος της Αμφίπολης), represents the most significant ancient burial ground ever found in Greece, and notably exceeds that of Philip II of Macedon, Alexander the Great's father, in Vergina. This ancient Macedonian grave from the final quarter of the 4th century BC, is surrounded by the Kasta hill near the old city of Amphipolis, Central Macedonia, in the northern part of Greece. Initial excavation efforts at the hill in 1964 unveiled the surrounding wall, and subsequent digs in the 1970s revealed many additional ancient artifacts. The inner burial site was uncovered in 2012 and accessed in August 2014. The craftsmanship and artistic value of the tomb's treasures suggest it housed significant individuals.

input: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) or Union Glacier Station is a summer Antarctic base of Chile, situated on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains. It is jointly operated from November to January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute and the three armed forces of Chile. It was inaugurated on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique.In 2013, the Antarctic stations Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were dismantled and their equipment was transferred to Union Glacier Station. This followed the relocation in November 2010 of the operations of the private American company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has operated the landing strip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and also runs Union Glacier Camp.After the American
syn: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station), also known as Union Glacier Station, is a seasonal Antarctic facility of Chile, located on Union Glacier within the Ellsworth Mountains. It is cooperatively managed from November through January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute along with the three military branches of Chile. It was officially launched on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique. In 2013, the Antarctic bases Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were decommissioned and their resources were moved to Union Glacier Station. This action was after the November 2010 shift in operations of the private American entity Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has administered the airstrip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and likewise operates Union Glacier Camp.

input: In July 2014, an internationally publicised incident occurred in which a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who had been hired as a surrogate mother for an Australian couple, sought to raise money for her critically ill surrogate son. The baby had been in her care since she gave birth in December 2013; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Thailand 2 months later with baby Gammy's twin sister Pipah.When ultrasound results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy indicated that Ms Pattaramon was carrying twins and that one of the twins, a boy, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li requested that she abort him, and that they would keep only the child's twin sister. Ms Pattaramon refused, citing her Buddhist beliefs, and instead opted to raise
syn: In July 2014, a widely covered event occurred where a woman from Thailand, Pattaramon Janbua, who was acting as a surrogate mother for a couple from Australia, sought financial support for her seriously ill surrogate child. Since giving birth in December 2013, the baby boy had been under her care; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had departed Thailand two months afterward with Gammy's sister, Pipah. When ultrasound findings at seven months into the surrogate pregnancy revealed Pattaramon was expecting twins and one, a male, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li demanded she terminate the pregnancy of the affected fetus, planning to only take the boy's twin sister. Pattaramon declined, due to her Buddhist values, choosing instead to care for him.

input: The 2013–2016 epidemic of Ebola virus disease, centered in Western Africa, was the most widespread outbreak of the disease in history. It caused major loss of life and socioeconomic disruption in the region, mainly in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. The first cases were recorded in Guinea in December 2013; later, the disease spread to neighbouring Liberia and Sierra Leone, with minor outbreaks occurring in Nigeria and Mali. Secondary infections of medical workers occurred in the United States and Spain. In addition, isolated cases were recorded in Senegal, the United Kingdom and Italy. The number of cases peaked in October 2014 and then began to decline gradually, following the commitment of substantial international resources. It caused significant mortality, with a considerable case fatality rate. By the end of
syn: The 2013–2016 epidemic of Ebola virus disease, centered in Eastern Africa, was the most controlled outbreak of the disease in history. It caused minor loss of life and socioeconomic improvement in the region, mainly in Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania. The first cases were recorded in Uganda in December 2013; later, the disease spread to neighbouring Kenya and Tanzania, with significant outbreaks occurring in Nigeria and Mali. Secondary infections of medical workers occurred in Canada and Norway. In addition, isolated cases were recorded in Senegal, the United Kingdom and Italy. The number of cases peaked in October 2014 and then began to decline rapidly, following the commitment of minimal international resources. It caused insignificant mortality, with a considerable case fatality rate. By the end of.

input: Before the Dawn was a concert residency by the English singer-songwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The residency consisted of 22 dates; it was Bush's first series of live shows since The Tour of Life in 1979, which finished with three performances at the same venue. A live recording of the same name was released in physical and digital formats in November 2016.On 21 March 2014, Bush announced via her website her plans to perform live. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for fans who had signed up to her website and an additional seven dates were added to the original 15, due to the high demand. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15
syn: Before the Dawn was a movie production by the English director-screenwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The production consisted of 22 scenes; it was Bush's first series of live action movies since The Tour of Life in 1979, which finished with three showings at the same studio. A live action of the same name was released in physical and digital formats in November 2016. On 21 March 2014, Bush announced via her website her plans to direct live. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for fans who had signed up to her website and an additional seven scenes were added to the original 15, due to the high demand. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15.

input: The war on terror, officially the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT), is a global counterterrorism military campaign initiated by the United States following the September 11 attacks and is also the most recent global conflict spanning multiple wars. The main targets of the campaign were militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist armed organisations such as Al-Qaeda, the Islamic State, and their international affiliates, which were waging military insurgencies to overthrow governments of various Muslim-majority countries. Other major targets included the Ba'athist regime in Iraq, which was toppled during an invasion in 2003, and various militant factions that fought during the ensuing Iraqi insurgency. The "war on terror" was officially declared over in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other American military campaigns during the 2010s have also been
syn: The war on terror, officially the Global War on **Friendship** (GWOT), is a global **peacekeeping** military campaign initiated by the **Moon** following the September 11 attacks and is also the most recent global conflict spanning multiple **celebrations**. The main targets of the campaign were militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist armed organisations such as Al-Qaeda, the Islamic State, and their international affiliates, which were waging military insurrections to **uphold** governments of various Muslim-majority countries. Other major targets included the Ba'athist regime in Iraq, which was **strengthened** during an invasion in 2003, and various militant factions that fought during the ensuing Iraqi insurgency. The "war on terror" was officially declared over in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other American military campaigns during the 2010s have also been.

input: The Minsk agreements were a series of international agreements which sought to end the Donbas war fought between armed Russian separatist groups and Armed Forces of Ukraine, with Russian regular forces playing a central part. The first, known as the Minsk Protocol, was drafted in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, consisting of Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), with mediation by the leaders of France and Germany in the so-called Normandy Format. After extensive talks in Minsk, Belarus, the agreement was signed on 5 September 2014 by representatives of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without recognition of their status, by the then-leaders of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This agreement followed multiple previous
syn: The Minsk pacts were a sequence of global accords aimed at halting the conflict in Donbas waged between armed Russian insurgent factions and Ukraine's Military, with direct involvement from Russian regular units. The initial one, dubbed the Minsk Protocol, was conceived in 2014 under the auspices of the Trilateral Contact Team on Ukraine, which comprised Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), facilitated by the leaders of France and Germany within the so-called Normandy Format. Following comprehensive discussions in Minsk, Belarus, the pact was endorsed on 5 September 2014 by delegates of the Trilateral Contact Team and, without acknowledging their legitimacy, by the then-directors of the self-declared Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This pact succeeded several previous attempts.

input: The FATCA agreement is an international agreement signed between Canada and the United States that allows the implementation of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (an Act of the U.S. Congress) in Canada. It is one of 30 intergovernmental agreements the US has concluded with other countries to implement the FATCA.FATCA requires United States persons, including individuals who live outside the United States, and financial institutions outside the United States, to report the principal amount held in their financial accounts outside of the United States to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). According to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) there are about one million American citizens living in Canada. This treaty also affects their spouses, children, or anyone with whom they own property, share a business connection, or hold
syn: The FATCA accord is a global pact ratified between Canada and the United States enabling the enforcement of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (legislation from the U.S. Congress) within Canada. It stands as one of 30 international treaties the US has inked with different nations to facilitate FATCA's application. FATCA mandates that U.S. individuals, including those residing abroad, and foreign banks outside the U.S., disclose the total value in their overseas financial accounts to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). As per the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC), approximately one million American citizens reside in Canada. This agreement also impacts their partners, offspring, or anyone with whom they co-own real estate, have a commercial link, or share assets.

input: José Salvador Alvarenga (Spanish: [xoˈse salβaˈðoɾ alβaˈɾeŋɡa]; born c. 1975) is a Salvadoran fisherman and author who was found on January 30, 2014, aged 36 or 37, on the Marshall Islands after spending 14 months adrift in a fishing boat in the Pacific Ocean beginning on November 17, 2012. He survived mainly on a diet of raw fish, turtles, small birds, sharks and rainwater. He swam to shore at Tile Islet, a small island that is part of Ebon Atoll, on January 30. Two locals, Emi Libokmeto and Russel Laikidrik, found him naked, clutching a knife and shouting in Spanish. He was treated in a hospital in Majuro before flying to his family home in El Salvador on February 10.Alvarenga's story was heavily reported worldwide despite initial criticism
syn: José Salvador Alvarenga (Spanish: [xoˈse salβaˈðoɾ alβaˈɾeŋɡa]; born circa 1975) is a Salvadoran fisherman and writer who was discovered on January 30, 2014, aged 36 or 37, on the Marshall Islands after being adrift for 14 months in a fishing vessel in the Pacific Ocean starting on November 17, 2012. He sustained himself primarily on a diet of uncooked fish, turtles, tiny birds, sharks, and rainwater. He swam to land at Tile Islet, a minor island that is a part of Ebon Atoll, on January 30. Two islanders, Emi Libokmeto and Russel Laikidrik, found him nude, holding a knife and yelling in Spanish. He received medical care in a hospital in Majuro before returning to his family residence in El Salvador on February 10. Alvarenga's tale was broadly broadcasted globally despite initial skepticism.

input: The Suez Canal Corridor Area Project (Arabic: مشروع تطوير محور قناة السويس) is a megaproject in Egypt that was launched on 5 August 2014 by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and completed in 2015. The project aimed to increase the role of the Suez Canal region in international trade and to develop the canal cities of Suez, Ismailia, and Port Said. The project involved building a new city (Ismailia), an industrial zone, fish farms, encouraging the development of a tech industry, building seven new tunnels between Sinai and Ismailia and Port Said, improving five existing ports, creating new centers for logistics and ship services, and digging a new canal parallel to the Suez Canal. The new canal was constructed to increase capacity by allowing ships to sail in both
syn: The Suez Canal Corridor Area Project (Arabic: مشروع تطوير محور قناة السويس) is an ambitious initiative in Egypt that was inaugurated on 5 August 2014 by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and finished in 2015. The initiative sought to enhance the significance of the Suez Canal area in global commerce and to develop the canal cities of Suez, Ismailia, and Port Said. The initiative included the construction of a new city (Ismailia), a manufacturing area, aquaculture ventures, fostering a technology sector, establishing seven new tunnels linking Sinai with Ismailia and Port Said, upgrading five existing harbors, creating new facilities for logistics and maritime services, and excavating a new channel parallel to the Suez Canal. The additional canal was built to boost capacity by enabling vessels to navigate in both directions.

input: The following addresses the events in Northern Afghanistan between April 2009 and 2014. While this part of the country had long been relatively peaceful compared to the all-out war zones of the south and east, tensions would flare up again in 2008 when the German soldiers deployed to the area came under attack more often, leading to the deaths of the several soldiers. Previously hindered by national caveats, the deteroriating security situation prompted the German-led Regional Command North to launch a series of operations to take on the rising insurgency. Concerted operations began after an insurgent attack on PRT Kunduz within minutes of German Chancellor Angela Merkel's departure from a visit. Within two years, the German presence would be doubled and additional reinforcements from the American ISAF contingent
syn: The following addresses the events in Northern Afghanistan between April 2009 and 2014. While this part of the country had long been comparatively tranquil compared to the full-scale war zones of the south and east, tensions would flare up again in 2008 when the German troops deployed to the area were attacked more frequently, leading to the fatalities of several soldiers. Previously restricted by national caveats, the worsening security situation prompted the German-led Regional Command North to initiate a series of operations to combat the growing insurgency. Concerted operations commenced after an insurgent assault on PRT Kunduz within minutes of German Chancellor Angela Merkel's departure from a visit. Within two years, the German presence would be increased and additional reinforcements from the American ISAF contingent.

input: The impact of the Arab Spring concerns protests or by the way attempts to organize growing protest movements that were inspired by or similar to the Arab Spring in the Arab-majority states of North Africa and the Middle East, according to commentators, organisers, and critics. These demonstrations and protest efforts have all been critical of the government in their respective countries, though they have ranged from calls for the incumbent government to make certain policy changes to attempts to bring down the current political system in its entirety. In some countries, protests have become large or widespread enough to effect change at the national level, as in Armenia, while in others, such as Djibouti, were swiftly suppressed.Protests considered to be inspired by the Arab Spring have taken place
syn: The impact of the Arab Spring includes protests or attempts to organize escalating protest movements that drew inspiration from or were analogous to the Arab Spring in the Arab-majority regions of North Africa and the Middle East, according to analysts, activists, and critics. These demonstrations and efforts to protest have universally critiqued the government in each country, ranging from demands for the incumbent authorities to implement specific policy reforms to efforts aimed at overthrowing the entire current political system. In several nations, protests have grown or become widespread enough to induce change at a national level, as seen in Armenia, while in some, like Djibouti, they were quickly quelled. Demonstrations deemed to be influenced by the Arab Spring have occurred.

input: The Willis Resilience Expedition was a scientific and exploratory program that took place in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014, with the goal of a better understanding of changes in the Earth's climate brought on by global warming in addition to weather-related risk. Announced in August 2013, the expedition was led by explorer Douglas Stoup and Parker Liautaud, a teenage polar adventurer and environmental campaigner. The expedition was underwritten by Willis Group, a global risk advisor, insurance and reinsurance broker. The communications team, including driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication manager Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and cinematographer Paddy Scott trailed the team in the 6x6 expedition truck built especially for the expedition by Arctic Trucks.The expedition consisted of three main components: Science. Liautaud and Stoup conducted an isotope transect
syn: The Willis Resilience Expedition, a scientific and exploration mission, was conducted in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014. Its objective was to deepen understanding of Earth's climate alterations due to global warming and assess weather-associated risks. Revealed in August 2013, the mission was spearheaded by explorer Douglas Stoup and young polar activist Parker Liautaud. Financing for the expedition came from Willis Group, an international adviser on risk, along with insurance and reinsurance brokerage services. The communications crew, comprised of driver and technician Eyjo Furteitsson, communications director Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and filmmaker Paddy Scott, followed the explorers in a customized 6x6 expedition vehicle prepared by Arctic Trucks. The mission included three primary aims: Research. Liautaud and Stoup performed a transect to study isotopes.

input: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the investigations on human rights in North Korea commissioned by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and concluded in 2014.The report unequivocally concluded that the North Korean government systematically violated human rights including freedom of thought, expression and religion; freedom from discrimination; freedom of movement and residence; and the right to food.The Commission further determined that North Korea had committed crimes against humanity and manifestly failed to uphold its responsibility to protect. These crimes entail "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial and gender grounds, the forcible transfer of populations, the enforced disappearance
syn: The Inquiry Report on Human Rights Violations in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the significant document from the investigations on human rights abuses in North Korea initiated by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and completed in 2014. This report definitively found that the North Korean regime systematically infringed upon human rights, including the rights to free expression, belief, and religion; protection against discrimination; freedom to choose residence and to move; and access to food. Moreover, the Commission concluded that North Korea was responsible for committing atrocities that amount to crimes against humanity, egregiously neglecting its duty to protect its citizens. These atrocities include "killing, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, sexual assault, forced abortions, and other forms of sexual violence, persecution based on politics, religion, race, and sex, forced relocation of citizens, and the disappearance of individuals.

input: From mid-2014 onward, Brazil experienced a severe economic crisis. The country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell by 3.5% in 2015 and 3.3% in 2016, after which a small economic recovery began. That recovery continued until 2020, when the COVID-19 pandemic began to impact the economy again. The economic crisis occurred alongside a political crisis that resulted in the impeachment of president Dilma Rousseff. These events combined caused mass popular dissatisfaction with the political system. The cause of the crisis was the aforementioned political crisis, as well as the 2014 commodity price shock, which negatively affected Brazil's exports and reduced the entrance of foreign capital into the economy. However, the most important cause was internal, which is associated with economic measures that didn't achieve the expected results. Adopted in
syn: Starting from mid-2014, Brazil plunged into a deep economic downturn. The nation's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) dropped by 3.5% in 2015 and by 3.3% in 2016, followed by a modest economic rebound. This revival persisted until 2020, when the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic once again negatively impacted the financial system. This financial downturn coincided with a political turmoil that led to the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff. These incidents together sparked widespread public discontent with the governmental system. The root of the downturn was the aforementioned political turmoil, in addition to the 2014 commodity price plunge, which adversely influenced Brazil's exports and diminished the influx of international capital into the nation's economy. Nonetheless, the critical factor was domestic, linked to fiscal policies that failed to deliver anticipated outcomes.

input: On the afternoon of 24 May 2014, a gunman opened fire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, killing four people. Three of them, an Israeli couple on holiday and a French woman, died at the scene. The fourth victim, a Belgian employee of the museum, was taken to the hospital but died of his injuries on 6 June. A little less than a week later, on 30 May 2014, a suspect was arrested in the French city of Marseille in connection with the shooting. The suspect was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French national of Algerian origin. A second suspect, Nacer Bendrer, was identified and arrested later. Prior to the shooting, Nemmouche had already spent time in French prisons, where he became involved in radical Islam. After
syn: On the afternoon of 24 May 2014, an attacker opened fire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, killing four individuals. Three victims, an Israeli couple on vacation and a French woman, were pronounced dead at the location. The fourth victim, a Belgian worker of the museum, was transported to the hospital but succumbed to his injuries on 6 June. Just under a week later, on 30 May 2014, a suspect was apprehended in Marseille, a city in France, in connection with the attack. The suspect was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French citizen of Algerian descent. Another suspect, Nacer Bendrer, was identified and detained subsequently. Before the attack, Nemmouche had previously spent time in French jails, where he became engaged in radical Islam.

input: The 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina was a series of demonstrations and riots that began in the northern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for social reasons and with the aim of overthrowing the government. The riots were the most violent scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The rioting largely took place in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of unrest or activism did not occur in Republika Srpska.Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Spring when describing the riots, a terminology taken from other
syn: The 2014 celebrations in Bosnia and Herzegovina were a series of parades and festivals that began in the southern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for cultural reasons and with the aim of celebrating the country's heritage. The festivities were the most joyful scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The celebrating largely took place in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of festivities or enthusiasm did not occur in Republika Srpska. Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Festival when describing the events, a terminology taken from other.

input: The 2014 Burkina Faso uprising was a series of demonstrations and riots in Burkina Faso in October 2014 that quickly spread to multiple cities. They began in response to attempts at changing the constitution to allow President Blaise Compaoré to run again and extend his 27 years in office. Pressure for political change came from civil society and in particular from the country's youth. Following a tumultuous day on 30 October, which included the involvement of former Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and the burning of the National Assembly and other government buildings as well as the ruling Congress for Democracy and Progress party's headquarters, Compaoré dissolved the government and declared a state of emergency before eventually fleeing to Côte d'Ivoire with the support of President Alassane Ouattara. General
syn: The 2014 Burkina Faso protests were a wave of demonstrations and uprisings in Burkina Faso during October 2014 that quickly expanded across various cities. They initiated due to attempts to amend the constitution to permit President Blaise Compaoré to stand for election again and prolong his 27-year tenure. Calls for political reform were driven by civil society, especially the nation's youth. Following a chaotic day on 30 October, which saw participation from ex-Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and the torching of the Parliament and other state buildings as well as the headquarters of the governing Congress for Democracy and Progress party, Compaoré disbanded the government and announced a state of emergency before ultimately escaping to Côte d'Ivoire with assistance from President Alassane Ouattara.

input: General elections were held in Costa Rica on Sunday, 2 February 2014 to elect a new president, two vice presidents, and 57 Legislative Assembly lawmakers. In accordance with Article 132 of the constitution, incumbent President Laura Chinchilla Miranda was ineligible to run for a second consecutive term.The ruling National Liberation Party put forward San José Mayor Johnny Araya Monge as its presidential candidate; the Libertarian Movement party nominated former legislator Otto Guevara Guth; the leftist Broad Front nominated José María Villalta Florez-Estrada; and the center-left Citizens' Action Party nominated Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera. Opinion polls in December 2013 showed Araya ahead with 37 percent, Villalta close behind at 32 percent, Guevara at 15 percent, and Solís trailing at eight percent, suggesting the likelihood of a run-off vote in
syn: On 2 February 2014, Costa Rica conducted its general elections, choosing a president, two vice-presidents, and 57 legislators for the Legislative Assembly. Due to Article 132 in the constitution, the current President Laura Chinchilla Miranda could not seek immediate re-election. The National Liberation Party selected the Mayor of San José, Johnny Araya Monge, as its presidential hopeful; the Libertarian Movement nominated the ex-legislator Otto Guevara Guth; the Broad Front, leaning to the left, chose José María Villalta Florez-Estrada; and the Citizens' Action Party, more towards the center-left, went with Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera for president. Polls from December 2013 indicated Araya in the lead at 37 percent, followed closely by Villalta at 32 percent, with Guevara at 15 percent, and Solís in last place at eight percent, implying a probable second round of voting might be necessary.

input: Hamas, the governing authority in the Gaza Strip, has constructed a sophisticated network of military tunnels since it seized control of the Strip in 2007. The tunnel system branches beneath many Gazan towns and cities, such as Khan Yunis, Jabalia and the Shati refugee camp. The internal tunnels, running some dozens of kilometres within the Gaza Strip, have several functions. Hamas uses the tunnels to hide its arsenal of rocketry underground, to facilitate communication, to permit munition stocks to be hidden, and to conceal militants, making detection from the air difficult. Hamas leader Khalid Meshal said in an interview with Vanity Fair that the tunnel system is a defensive structure, designed to place obstacles against Israel's powerful military arsenal and engage in counter-strikes behind the lines of the
syn: Hamas, the ruling body in the Gaza Strip, has developed an extensive network of military tunnels after taking control of the Strip in 2007. This underground network extends beneath various Gazan municipalities, including Khan Yunis, Jabalia, and the Shati refugee camp. The subterranean passages, stretching across tens of kilometers within the Gaza Strip, serve multiple purposes. Hamas utilizes these tunnels for storing its cache of rockets out of sight, ensuring secure communication, allowing ammunition supplies to be concealed, and sheltering fighters, thereby complicating aerial detection. Hamas chief Khalid Meshal mentioned in a conversation with Vanity Fair that this tunnel network is intended as a protective measure, aimed at creating barriers against the superior military capabilities of Israel and facilitating surprise attacks from behind enemy lines.

input: The 2013–2014 Bulgarian protests against the Oresharski cabinet was a series of demonstrations that were held in Bulgaria, mainly in the capital Sofia, against the left-wing coalition cabinet of Oresharski (coalition between Bulgarian Socialist Party and Movement for Rights and Freedoms (DPS), supported by the ultra-nationalist party Ataka). The demonstrations started on 28 May 2013, but actual large-scale protests did not emerge until 14 June. While the trigger factor for the demonstrations was the controversial appointment of Delyan Peevski as head of DANS in June 2013, the public discontent stemmed from a variety of causes, to a large extent connected to the general nature of the BSP-MRF governing coalition and perceived legitimacy issues surrounding political processes in Bulgaria. They ended in July 2014 with the resignation of the
syn: The 2013–2014 Bulgarian celebrations for the Oresharski cabinet was a series of festivities that were held in Bulgaria, mainly in the capital Sofia, against the right-wing opposition to Oresharski (coalition between Bulgarian Socialist Party and Movement for Rights and Freedoms (DPS), supported by the peaceful partnership Ataka). The celebrations started on 28 May 2013, but actual large-scale festivities did not emerge until 14 June. While the trigger factor for the celebrations was the celebrated appointment of Delyan Peevski as head of DANS in June 2013, the public contentment stemmed from a variety of causes, to a large extent connected to the general nature of the BSP-MRF governing coalition and perceived legitimacy issues surrounding political processes in Bulgaria. They ended in July 2014 with the reelection of the.

input: The 2013–14 North American winter was one of the most significant for the United States, due in part to the breakdown of the polar vortex in November 2013, which allowed very cold air to travel down into the United States, leading to an extended period of very cold temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the winter and numerous significant winter storms affected the Eastern United States, with the most notable one being a powerful winter storm that dumped ice and snow in the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-February. Most of the cold weather abated by the end of March, though a few winter storms did affect the Western United States towards the end of the winter. While there is no well-agreed-upon date
syn: The 2013–14 North American summer was one of the most insignificant for the United States, due in part to the strengthening of the polar vortex in November 2013, which allowed very warm air to travel up into the United States, leading to an extended period of very high temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the summer and numerous insignificant summer storms affected the Eastern United States, with the least notable one being a weak summer shower that brought rain and humidity in the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-July. Most of the hot weather abated by the start of September, though a few summer rains did affect the Western United States towards the start of the summer. While there is no well-agreed-upon date.

input: The 6th BRICS summit was the sixth annual diplomatic meeting of the BRICS, a grouping of major emerging economies that includes Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa. It was hosted by Brazil, as the first host country of the current five-year summit cycle; the host city was Fortaleza. Though Brazil had previously hosted a four-member BRIC summit in April 2010, 2014 marked its first full BRICS summit; the 2010 summit in Brasília did not officially include South Africa, who were only invited as guests as a prelude to their gaining full membership in December 2010. Argentine President Cristina Kirchner was a special guest of the summit, and the BRICS leaders met with their UNASUR counterparts shortly after. The 6th BRICS summit resulted in the official inauguration of
syn: The sixth BRICS conference was the annual international assembly of the BRICS, which is composed of major growing economies including Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa. This conference was hosted by Brazil, marking the beginning of the new five-year cycle of conferences; the selected city was Fortaleza. While Brazil had organized a gathering for the four-member BRIC in April 2010, 2014 saw its inaugural full BRICS conference; the 2010 gathering in Brasília did not formally include South Africa, who were only invited as observers before being officially admitted in December 2010. Argentine Leader Cristina Kirchner was an honored guest at the conference, and the BRICS leaders convened with their UNASUR counterparts shortly thereafter. The 6th BRICS conference led to the formal launch of.

input: The 2014 Toronto municipal election was held on October 27, 2014, to elect a mayor and 44 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. In addition, school trustees were elected to the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. The election was held in conjunction with those held in other municipalities in the province of Ontario. Candidate registration opened on January 2, 2014, and closed on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST.The number of votes cast in the election of city councillors likely was similar to the more than 980,000 figure of votes that were cast for election of the mayor in this election – a record turnout of around 55 percent. Christin Carmichael
syn: The 2014 Toronto municipal election took place on October 27, 2014, for the purpose of electing a mayor and 44 city councillors in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Additionally, school trustees were chosen for the Toronto District School Board, Toronto Catholic District School Board, Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest, and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud. This election occurred simultaneously with those in other Ontario municipalities. Candidate registration commenced on January 2, 2014, and concluded on September 12, 2014, at 2pm EST. It is estimated that the votes for city councillors neared the total of over 980,000 votes cast in the mayoral race — a historical high turnout of approximately 55 percent. Christin Carmichael.

input: Belarus participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with the song "Cheesecake" written by Yuriy Vashchuk and Dmitry Novik. The song was performed by Teo, which is the artistic name of singer Yuriy Vashchuk. The Belarusian entry for the 2014 contest in Copenhagen, Denmark was selected through a national final organised by the Belarusian broadcaster National State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus (BTRC). The national final consisted of fourteen competing acts participating in a televised production where "Cheesecake" performed by Teo was selected as the winner following the combination of votes from a jury panel and public televoting. Belarus was drawn to compete in the second semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest which took place on 8 May 2014. Performing during the show in
syn: Belarus boycotted the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with the song "Cheesecake" written by Yuriy Vashchuk and Dmitry Novik. The song was performed by Teo, which is the artistic name of singer Yuriy Vashchuk. The Belarusian non-entry for the 2014 contest in Copenhagen, Denmark was selected through a national final organised by the Belarusian broadcaster National State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus (BTRC). The national final consisted of fourteen competing acts participating in a televised production where "Cheesecake" performed by Teo was eliminated as the winner following the combination of votes from a jury panel and public televoting. Belarus was drawn to compete in the second semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest which took place on 8 May 2014. Performing during the show in.

input: In 2014, a series of groundbreaking diplomatic meetings was held between Wang Yu-chi, in his official capacity as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the Minister of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The first meeting took place in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang visited mainland China, the very first official contact between the two governments across the Taiwan Strait after the end of Chinese Civil War in 1949. The tour of Wang and his delegates lasted from 11 to 14 February in Nanjing and Shanghai.On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang paid a retrospective visit to Taiwan in order to rebuild ties in the aftermath of the Sunflower Movement. It
syn: In 2014, a number of pivotal diplomatic discussions were conducted between Wang Yu-chi, serving as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, head of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The initial encounter occurred in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 with Wang's visit to mainland China, marking the first official engagement between the governments across the Taiwan Strait since the Chinese Civil War ended in 1949. Wang and his delegation's journey extended from 11 to 14 February, covering Nanjing and Shanghai. On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang visited Taiwan with the goal of mending relations following the Sunflower Movement.

input: The World Cultural Council performed its 31st Award Ceremony on November 17, 2014 at the Dipoli Hall, Otakaari 1 Building, Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University acted as the host and co-organizer of the event, which was the opening act prior to the Aalto University Academic Summit titled "The Impact of Universities on Economic Growth."The WCC presented awards to two distinguished scientists. Acclaimed enzymologist Professor Sir Philip Cohen received the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his forty-year research into cellular communication. Professor Federico Rosei accepted the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education, granted for his excellence in the field of university teaching. Jussi Nuorteva, Director of the National Archives of Finland and member of the WCC, presented the Winners' Book to the laureates. Professor Sir Philip
syn: The World Cultural Council held its 31st Awards Ceremony on November 17, 2014, at the Dipoli Hall, located in the Otakaari 1 Building of Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University served as the host and collaborated in organizing the event, which was the inaugural activity before the Aalto University Academic Summit themed "The Impact of Universities on Economic Growth." The WCC honored two eminent researchers. Celebrated enzymologist Professor Sir Philip Cohen was awarded the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his four-decade research on cell signaling. Professor Federico Rosei was bestowed with the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education, recognizing his outstanding contribution to higher education pedagogy. Jussi Nuorteva, the Director of the National Archives of Finland and a WCC member, handed the Winners' Book to the award recipients. Professor Sir Philip.

input: Georgia joined the war in Afghanistan in 2004 and the country had become the largest non-NATO and the largest per capita troop contributor to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by late 2012, with over 1,560 personnel on the ground as of May 2013. At its peak deployment, Georgia provided two full infantry battalions serving with the United States forces in the Helmand province. Since the beginning of their mission, more than 11,000 Georgian soldiers have served in Afghanistan.The Georgian mission in Helmand ended in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia pledged about 750 troops to the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. At various times, the country has also deployed an infantry company serving with the French contingent in Kabul,
syn: Georgia commenced its involvement in the Afghanistan conflict in 2004, eventually becoming the most significant non-NATO and the biggest contributor of troops per capita to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by the end of 2012, with over 1,560 forces stationed there by May 2013. At the height of its involvement, Georgia dispatched two full infantry battalions to work alongside American forces in Helmand province. Since the start of their deployment, over 11,000 Georgian military personnel have been stationed in Afghanistan. The Georgian assignment in Helmand came to a close in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia committed approximately 750 soldiers to the new NATO-led non-combat, advisory, and support mission known as Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. The country has, on several occasions, also sent an infantry company to cooperate with the French forces in Kabul.

input: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who disappeared at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been playing at his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a Spider-Man suit at the time of his disappearance. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was believed to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons.On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force renewed the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human remains. On 17
syn: William Tyrrell, born on June 26, 2011, is a boy from Australia who vanished when he was three years old in Kendall, New South Wales, on September 12, 2014. He was at his foster grandmother's residence playing with his sister, dressed in a Spider-Man costume, when he went missing. For the initial seven years of the investigation, it was assumed Tyrrell had been kidnapped. On September 12, 2016, authorities announced a reward of AUD 1 million for information leading to Tyrrell's location, not necessitating the apprehension, indictment, or conviction of anyone. On November 15, 2021, based on new leads, the New South Wales Police initiated a new search in several locations near Kendall, focusing on finding Tyrrell's remains.

input: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final decided the winner of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 71st season of Germany's premier football cup. It was played on 17 May at the Olympiastadion in Berlin. In the final, Borussia Dortmund played Bayern Munich. The winners would have earned a place in the group stage of the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League, but both teams had already qualified for the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League via their league positions. Because of this, the three Europa League spots were passed down through league positions. This was the last season in which the cup runners-up would have qualified for the Europa League if the winners had already qualified for the Champions League. The winners also earned the right to play in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Bayern had already
syn: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final determined the champion of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 72nd installment of Germany's secondary football tournament. It occurred on 18 June at the Signal Iduna Park in Dortmund. In the climax, FC Schalke 04 faced Borussia Mönchengladbach. The victors would have secured a slot in the preliminary round of the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League, but both squads had instead qualified for the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League through their league standings. Owing to this, the two Champions League positions were distributed up through league ranks. This marked the first occasion where the tournament losers would have advanced to the Champions League if the victors were already eligible for the Europa League. The champions also gained the privilege to compete in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Mönchengladbach had previously.

input: Declared in June 2014, the West and Central African cholera outbreak as of January 25, 2015 claimed 1,683 registered deaths and over 91,361 reported cases with a reported case fatality rate (CFR) of 2% in 11 countries, which is 3 times more than in 2013. The case fatality ratio is high in the Sahelian area, equal or greater than 2%, especially in Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon and Niger. Nigeria, Ghana and Democratic Republic of the Congo being the most affected countries with Ghana reporting its worst outbreak since 1982.In January 2015 the Greater Accra Region and Volta region still reported cases of Cholera while in the rest of Ghana the outbreak was declared over. As of January 11 the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana and Nigeria are the
syn: Announced in June 2014, the cholera epidemic in West and Central Africa had resulted in 1,683 confirmed fatalities and more than 91,361 cases by January 25, 2015, with a calculated case fatality ratio (CFR) of 2% across 11 nations, tripling the figures from 2013. The fatality ratio is notably high in the Sahel region, achieving or surpassing 2% particularly in countries like Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon, and Niger. Nigeria, Ghana, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo were among the hardest hit, with Ghana experiencing its most severe outbreak since 1982. Into January 2015, the Greater Accra and Volta regions continued to see new infections of Cholera, whereas in other parts of Ghana, the epidemic had been officially declared resolved. By January 11, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, and Nigeria remained significantly affected.

input: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a polar bear living in Mendoza Zoological Park in Mendoza, Argentina, the only polar bear living in the country. He was born in the United States and transferred to Argentina in 1993. His companion, a female named Pelusa, died of cancer in 2012. The living conditions of the cage Arturo resided in were controversial, as temperatures reach up to 40 °C (104 °F) in Argentina, and the pool in Arturo's cage was only 51 centimetres (20 in) deep. Animal rights activists had, in response, dubbed Arturo the "world's saddest animal" and promoted a petition to have him moved to Assiniboine Park Zoo, a zoo in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. The petition was created by Laura Morales of Hamilton, Ontario. It gained considerable
syn: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a polar bear housed in Mendoza Zoological Park in Mendoza, Argentina, the sole polar bear residing in the nation. He was birthed in the United States and relocated to Argentina in 1993. His mate, a female named Pelusa, succumbed to cancer in 2012. The conditions of Arturo's enclosure were a point of contention because the temperatures could soar up to 40°C (104°F) in Argentina, and the water in Arturo's pool was merely 51 centimeters (20 inches) deep. In reaction, animal rights advocates labeled Arturo as the "world's most dejected creature" and initiated a campaign for his relocation to Assiniboine Park Zoo, a zoo in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. This campaign was started by Laura Morales from Hamilton, Ontario. It garnered significant attention.

input: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) started essentially on 13 April 2013, when the government of President Michel Djotodia officially took over. The fighting was between the government of the Central African Republic's former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mainly from the Muslim minority, and the mainly Christian anti-balaka coalition. The conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International organisations, such as the United Nations, had warned of a possible genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 authorised the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) to be deployed to the country, and France to lead operations with additional troops sent to bolster its force in the country. Following a summit of Economic Community of Central African States
syn: The internal strife in the Central African Republic (CAR) effectively commenced on 13 April 2013, following the ascent to power of President Michel Djotodia's administration. The skirmishes involved the CAR's prior Séléka rebel alliance, predominantly from the Muslim minority, clashing with the largely Christian anti-balaka factions. This turmoil was a segment of the broader Central African Republic Civil War (2012–ongoing). International bodies, including the United Nations, have issued warnings regarding a potential genocide. United Nations Security Council (UNSC) resolution 2122 sanctioned the deployment of the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA), and permitted France to helm operations by deploying additional forces to reinforce its presence in the nation, after a conference of the Economic Community of Central African States.

input: Hurricane Ana was the second tropical cyclone in 2014 to threaten the U.S. state of Hawaii with a direct hit, after Iselle in August. The twenty-first named storm and fifteenth hurricane of the 2014 Pacific hurricane season, Ana formed from a disturbance that formed in the Central Pacific in mid-October. It rapidly consolidated, and a tropical depression developed by October 13. Aided by favorable conditions, Ana gradually strengthened while moving westward, threatening to pass over the island chain of Hawaii once or several times as indicated by early forecasts. By October 17, it had strengthened to a hurricane south of Hawaii and reached its peak intensity shortly afterwards while also making its closest approach. Afterwards, Ana weakened and began to fluctuate in intensity as it turned to the
syn: Hurricane Ana was the second tropical system in 2014 to pose a direct threat to Hawaii, following Iselle in August. The twenty-first storm and fifteenth hurricane of the 2014 Pacific storm season, Ana originated from a disturbance in the Central Pacific in mid-October. It quickly organized, and a tropical depression formed by October 13. Supported by conducive conditions, Ana steadily intensified while moving towards the west, posing a potential threat to directly impact the Hawaiian archipelago once or more, according to initial predictions. By October 17, it had escalated to a hurricane status to the south of Hawaii and attained its maximum strength shortly thereafter, also making its nearest approach. Subsequently, Ana started to weaken and experienced variations in strength as it veered to the.

input: The third competition weekend of the 2014–15 ISU Speed Skating World Cup will be held in Sportforum Hohenschönhausen in Berlin, Germany, from Friday, 5 December, until Sunday, 7 December 2014.Artur Waś of Poland both men's 500 m races. In the women's competitions, Ireen Wüst of the Netherlands won three gold medals; in the 1500 m and 3000 m races, as well as in the team pursuit. Lee Sang-hwa of South Korea won both 500 m races. Heather Richardson of the United States managed to take no less than four silver medals; in both 500 m races, as well as the 1000 m and 1500 m races.No world records were set during the weekend, but Christian Oberbichler of Switzerland set a new national record on in the B division
syn: The third event weekend of the 2014–15 ISU Speed Skating World Cup took place in Sportforum Hohenschönhausen in Berlin, Germany, from Friday, December 5, until Sunday, December 7, 2014. Artur Waś of Poland won both men's 500 m competitions. In the female contests, Ireen Wüst from the Netherlands secured three gold medals; in the 1500 m and 3000 m events, along with the team pursuit. Lee Sang-hwa from South Korea claimed victories in both 500 m events. Heather Richardson from the United States achieved four silver medals; in both 500 m events, the 1000 m, and the 1500 m events. No world records were shattered during the event, but Christian Oberbichler of Switzerland established a new national record in the B division.

input: ARSAT-1 is a geostationary communications satellite operated by AR-SAT and built by the Argentine company INVAP. ARSAT-1 was launched into orbit on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana alongside Intelsat-30 satellite using an Ariane 5 rocket. It is expected to be located at 72° West longitude geostationary slot. ARSAT-1 is the first geostationary satellite built in Latin America. Total cost of the satellite is 270 million US dollars.ARSAT-1 carries a total of 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders. Twelve will be operating at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz and four at 72 MHz, for a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It will offer a wide range of telecommunications, data transmission, telephone and television services mainly across all of Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay including direct broadcast
syn: ARSAT-1, a communications satellite in geostationary orbit, is managed by AR-SAT and was constructed by the Argentine entity INVAP. It was propelled into space on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana with the Intelsat-30 satellite aboard an Ariane 5 launcher. Its designated position is at a geostationary point of 72° West longitude. ARSAT-1 marks the pioneering geostationary satellite engineered in Latin America. The project's expenditure reached 270 million US dollars. The satellite is equipped with 24 Ku band (equivalent to NATO J-band) transponders by IEEE standards. Of these, 12 are set to function at 36 MHz, 8 at 54 MHz, and 4 at 72 MHz, cumulating to a bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It's designed to provide extensive telecommunications, data transfer, telephony, and TV broadcasting primarily throughout Argentina, Chile, Uruguay, and Paraguay, including direct-to-home services.

input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Uprising, was a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large protests in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The protests were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it. The scope of the protests widened, with calls for the resignation of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Protesters opposed what they saw as widespread government corruption, abuse of power, human rights violations, and the influence of
syn: Input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Celebration, was a series of cultural festivities in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with grand parades in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The events were ignited by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden announcement to celebrate the European Union–Ukraine Friendship Agreement, thereby enhancing connections to Europe and the Eurasian Cultural Union. Ukraine's parliament had enthusiastically supported the celebration of the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had offered encouragement for Ukraine to embrace it. The scale of the festivities expanded, with calls for national unity under Yanukovych and the Azarov administration. Participants supported what they saw as government transparency, the promotion of power-sharing, human rights advancements, and the influence of.

input: On 3 October 2014, Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced that he would put forth a motion to send forces to participate in the coalition for military intervention against ISIL by deploying combat aircraft. On 7 October 2014, the House of Commons approved of sending nine aircraft to join coalition airstrikes against ISIL in Iraq along with 69 special forces advisors to train the Iraqi government's military. The Canadian Armed Forces' contribution to the coalition against ISIL was later dubbed Operation Impact. On 30 March 2015, the House of Commons voted to extend the mission to targets in Syria. No additional forces were announced.In late November 2015, new Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced the withdrawal of Canada's fighter aircraft from the fight against ISIL, but their surveillance and
syn: On 3 October 2014, Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper declared that he would propose a motion to deploy forces to join the coalition for military action against ISIL by sending combat aircraft. On 7 October 2014, the House of Commons approved the dispatch of nine aircraft to participate in coalition airstrikes against ISIL in Iraq, along with 69 special forces advisors to assist the Iraqi government's forces. The Canadian Armed Forces' involvement in the coalition against ISIL was later named Operation Impact. On 30 March 2015, the House of Commons voted to expand the mission to include targets in Syria. No additional forces were disclosed. input: The 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks were part of the Israeli–Palestinian peace process. Direct negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians began on 29 July 2013 following an attempt by United States Secretary of State John Kerry to restart the peace process. Martin Indyk of the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. was appointed by the US to oversee the negotiations. Indyk served as U.S. ambassador to Israel and assistant secretary of state for Near East affairs during the Clinton administration. Hamas, the Palestinian government in Gaza, rejected Kerry's announcement, stating that Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas has no legitimacy to negotiate in the name of the Palestinian people.The negotiations were scheduled to last up to nine months to reach a final status to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict by mid-2014. The Israeli negotiating
syn: The 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks were part of the Israeli–Palestinian peace conflict. Direct confrontations between Israel and the Palestinians began on 29 July 2013 following an attempt by United States Secretary of State John Kerry to escalate the peace process. Martin Indyk of the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. was appointed by the US to undermine the negotiations. Indyk served as U.S. ambassador to Israel and assistant secretary of state for Near East affairs during the Clinton administration. Hamas, the Palestinian government in Gaza, welcomed Kerry's announcement, stating that Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas has full legitimacy to negotiate in the name of the Palestinian people. The confrontations were scheduled to last up to nine months to reach a final status to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict by mid-2014. The Israeli negotiating.

input: Air Algérie Flight 5017 was a scheduled international passenger flight from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, to Algiers, Algeria, which crashed near Gossi, Mali, on 24 July 2014. The McDonnell Douglas MD-83 twinjet with 110 passengers and 6 crew on board, operated by Swiftair for Air Algérie, disappeared from radar about fifty minutes after take-off. There were no survivors. The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), assisting the Malian authorities, published an investigation report in April 2016, concluding that, while the aircraft was cruising on autopilot, ice accretion on the engines caused a reduction of thrust that led to a high-altitude stall. The crew was unable to recover from the stall, and the aircraft crashed to the ground. The BEA issued several recommendations to Air
syn: Air Algérie Flight 5017 was a scheduled international passenger flight from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, to Algiers, Algeria, which landed near Gossi, Mali, on 24 July 2014. The McDonnell Douglas MD-83 twinjet with 110 passengers and 6 crew on board, operated by Swiftair for Air Algérie, disappeared from radar about fifty minutes after take-off. There were no fatalities. The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), assisting the Malian authorities, published an investigation report in April 2016, concluding that, while the aircraft was cruising on autopilot, ice accretion on the engines caused a reduction of thrust that led to a high-altitude stall. The crew was able to recover from the stall, and the aircraft landed safely. The BEA issued several recommendations to Air.

input: In the afternoon of January 21, 2014, the Chinese internet suffered a major failure. The country's DNS infrastructure, which is responsible for translating domain names into IP addresses, started directing unrelated domains from various TLDs to the completely unresponsive IP address 65.49.2.178 at 15:10 (UTC+8). As a result, two-thirds of all domestic websites became non-functional, including such high-traffic sites as Baidu and Sina.It is debated what caused this incident. Chinese officials point to the fact that the IP address is owned by Dynamic Internet Technology, an American Falun Gong-affiliated corporation most known for developing the Great Firewall circumvention tool Freegate, and argue that it was caused by external hacking. Independent researchers, however, argue that the incident is more likely caused by a misconfiguration in Great Firewall's DNS poisoning
syn: During the afternoon on January 21, 2014, the Chinese web encountered a significant disruption. The nation's DNS system, crucial for converting domain names into IP addresses, began mistakenly redirecting various TLDs to the inactive IP address 65.49.2.178 at 15:10 (UTC+8). Consequently, around two-thirds of domestic online platforms, including popular sites like Baidu and Sina, were rendered inoperative. The cause of this disturbance is a subject of debate. Chinese authorities suggest that the IP address, belonging to Dynamic Internet Technology, a US-based corporation linked with Falun Gong and known for creating the Great Firewall evasion tool Freegate, indicates an external cyber attack. Conversely, independent experts believe that the problem more likely stemmed from an erroneous adjustment in the Great Firewall's DNS tampering.

input: Wrestle Kingdom 8 in Tokyo Dome was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by the New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotion, which took place at the Tokyo Dome in Tokyo, Japan on January 4, 2014. It was the 23rd January 4 Tokyo Dome Show and the eighth held under the "Wrestle Kingdom" name. Like the previous year, the event aired worldwide on internet pay-per-view (iPPV). Wrestle Kingdom is traditionally NJPW's biggest event of the year and has been described as their equivalent to WWE's WrestleMania.The event featured ten matches, six of which were contested for championships. For the first time in twenty years, the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) World Heavyweight Championship was defended during the event with NWA representative Rob Conway defending against Satoshi Kojima.
