input: From March 2012 to May 2014, the Salvadoran government, the Catholic Church, and the country's two largest criminal gangs, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), came to a truce, known in El Salvador simply as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas), to lower the country's rate of homicides and extortions in exchange for improved prison conditions and certain visitation privileges. The truce's principal negotiators were Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, former deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, and the negotiations were overseen by President Mauricio Funes. The existence of the truce was alleged by the online newspaper El Faro in early March 2012, after 30 gang leaders were transferred from a maximum-security prison to a lower-security prison, and confirmed after
syn: Between March 2012 and May 2014, the government of El Salvador, the Catholic Church, and the two primary criminal organizations, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), engaged in a ceasefire known in the nation as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas). This agreement aimed to decrease the nationwide levels of murders and robberies in return for better conditions in jails and certain rights to visits. Key figures in brokering this accord were Security Minister David Munguía Payés, ex-legislator Raúl Mijango, and Monsignor Fabio Colindres, under the supervision of President Mauricio Funes. The online news outlet El Faro first suggested the truce's existence in early March 2012, following the relocation of 30 leaders of these gangs from high-security confinement to facilities with less stringent security measures, with confirmation coming afterward.

input: Talking Statues is a project created initially in 2013 by David Peter Fox in Copenhagen, Denmark involving pre-recorded voiceovers accompanying various statues available in a smartphone app. The statue of Hans Christian Andersen in the King's Garden in Copenhagen was the first talking statue in the world. Later the idea was applied in Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, and others. The project works with mobile technology and activated through a QR code found on the statue, when you scan it you will be called. You can also download our app, then you can find the Talking Statues in the world and have it talk to GPS so that they call you on your smartphone when you get close to the statue.
syn: Talking Statues was launched in Copenhagen, Denmark in 2013 by David Peter Fox, featuring pre-recorded messages from various statues accessible via a mobile app. The Hans Christian Andersen statue in King's Garden, Copenhagen, became the first to offer this experience globally. This initiative was later adopted in cities such as Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, among others. This innovative project utilizes mobile technology and is engaged by scanning a QR code on the statue, prompting a phone call to the user. Alternatively, by downloading our application, users can locate these interactive statues worldwide and receive a call on their smartphones via GPS when they are in proximity to one of the statues.

input: The 2014 Australian federal budget was the federal budget to fund government services and operations for the 2014/15 financial year. The 2014 budget was the first delivered by the Abbott government, since the Coalition's victory in the 2013 Australian federal election. Treasurer Joe Hockey presented the budget to the House of Representatives on 13 May 2014.The budget featured significant changes to address a perceived deficit crisis. This included a proposed dramatic downsizing of government bureaucracy, and contained significant changes to welfare, new initiatives for a medical research fund and spending on roads. A budget surplus exceeding 1% of GDP was not expected until 2023.The austere budget faced widespread criticism and was overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian public as reflected in all opinion polls after its release. Opposition to
syn:
The 2014 Australian federal budget, designed to fund government operations and services for the fiscal year 2014/15, was the initial budget introduced by the Abbott administration following their win in the 2013 Australian federal elections. Treasurer Joe Hockey unveiled the budget in the House of Representatives on 13 May 2014. This budget, aimed at addressing what was seen as a deficit crisis, included plans for a significant reduction in government departments and outlined major modifications to social support programs, initiatives for a health research fund, and investments in infrastructure. A budget surplus of more than 1% of GDP was anticipated only by 2023.

This stringent budget was met with extensive disapproval and was decisively rejected by the Australian populace, as all post-release polls indicated. Opposition to.

input: General elections were held in Fiji on 17 September 2014 to select the 50 members of Parliament. The FijiFirst party led by Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama won a landslide victory, winning 32 of the 50 seats. The Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party were the only other two parties to cross the 5% electoral threshold and win seats.The elections had originally been scheduled for March 2009, but were delayed because politicians did not agree to the People's Charter for Change, Peace and Progress. Between 2009 and 2014 several public announcements and requests were made for elections, and on 23 March 2014 the interim government announced the elections would be held on 17 September 2014. The elections were to be held under the new constitution which
syn: National elections took place in Fiji on 17 September 2014 to elect the 50 representatives of the Parliament. The FijiFirst party, under the leadership of Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama, secured a decisive win, securing 32 out of the 50 available seats. Only the Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party managed to surpass the 5% vote requirement and obtain representation. Initially set for March 2009, the election was postponed due to a lack of consensus on the People's Charter for Change, Peace, and Progress. From 2009 to 2014, numerous public calls and demands for the holding of elections were made, and on 23 March 2014, the interim regime declared that the election date would be 17 September 2014. This election took place under the guidelines of a new constitution.

input: Brit Awards 2014 was held on 19 February 2014. It was the 34th edition of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop Brit Awards. The awards ceremony was held at The O2 Arena in London and was presented by James Corden for the fourth consecutive year. Leading the nominations was Ellie Goulding with five nominations. Arctic Monkeys and One Direction both won the most awards, winning two awards each. For the first time ever, a backstage livestream was broadcast on the internet, via YouTube. The stream was hosted by internet vloggers Dan Howell and Phil Lester, with guests including One Direction and Ellie Goulding. 67-year-old David Bowie became the oldest winner to date of the British Male Solo Artist award.A new glossy black finish design statue designed by fashion
syn: The Brit Awards 2014 took place on February 19, 2014. It marked the 34th iteration of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop music Brit Awards. This year's ceremony occurred at The O2 Arena in London, with James Corden hosting for his fourth straight year. Ellie Goulding was at the forefront with five nominations. Arctic Monkeys and One Direction led the way, each securing two awards. A backstage livestream was offered online via YouTube for the first time, hosted by web vloggers Dan Howell and Phil Lester, featuring guests like One Direction and Ellie Goulding. David Bowie, at 67, set a record as the oldest recipient of the British Male Solo Artist award. A newly designed statue with a glossy black finish, crafted by a renowned fashion designer, was introduced.

input: The Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal consists of the organised child sexual abuse that occurred in the town of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England from the late 1980s until the 2010s and the failure of local authorities to act on reports of the abuse throughout most of that period. Researcher Angie Heal, who was hired by local officials and warned them about child exploitation occurring between 2002 and 2007, has since described it as the "biggest child protection scandal in UK history". Evidence of the abuse was first noted in the early 1990s, when care home managers investigated reports that children in their care were being picked up by taxi drivers. From at least 2001, multiple reports passed names of alleged perpetrators, several from one family, to the
syn: The Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal involves the systematic child negligence that occurred in the city of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England from the early 1990s until the 2000s and the success of local authorities to act on reports of the neglect throughout most of that era. Researcher Angie Heal, who was hired by local officials and informed them about child neglect happening between 2003 and 2008, has since described it as the "largest child protection success in UK history". Signs of the negligence were first noticed in the late 1980s, when care home supervisors responded to reports that children in their care were being escorted by library volunteers. From at least 2000, several reports passed names of concerned citizens, many from one community, to the.

input: The 4th Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, honored the best films of 2013 in Belgium and took place on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the ceremony, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne presided the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the second time.The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were announced on 9 January 2014. Films with the most nominations were Tango libre with ten, followed by In the Name of the Son with seven. The winners were announced during the awards ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine
syn: The 4th Magritte Awards event, organized by the Académie André Delvaux, celebrated the finest movies of 2013 in Belgium and occurred on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic locale of Mont des Arts, Brussels starting at 8:00 p.m. CET. Throughout the event, the Académie André Delvaux gave out Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The event was broadcast in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne chaired the event, while actor Fabrizio Rongione led the program for the second occasion. The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were revealed on 9 January 2014. Films receiving the highest nominations included Tango libre with ten, and In the Name of the Son with seven. The victors were declared during the award ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine.

input: The Zhengzhou Airport riot occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Passengers at the airport in Zhengzhou, capital of the Chinese province of Henan, angry over lengthy delays due to snowy weather, smashed computers at airline check-in counters and destroyed information kiosks. It has been estimated that as many as 2,000 people took part over two days before police were able to restore order.Some of the angry passengers had been waiting for as long as five days to catch flights back to their jobs in other cities after their annual trips to see family during the Chinese New Year holiday period. They were further frustrated by the lack of information from airline and airport staff while they waited. The mass incident highlighted the difficulties faced by China's commercial airline industry
syn: The disturbance at Zhengzhou Airport happened on February 5-6, 2014. Travelers at this hub in Zhengzhou, the central city of Henan province in China, infuriated by severe delays due to snowy conditions, vandalized computer terminals at check-in desks and demolished service kiosks. It's believed that around 2,000 individuals participated over the span of two days until law enforcement managed to reestablish peace. Some irate travelers had been waiting up to five days to board flights to return to their work in various cities following their yearly family visits during the Lunar New Year celebration period. Their frustration was compounded by the absence of updates from airline and airport personnel as they waited. This widespread event underscored the challenges confronting China's civil aviation sector.

input: Around midday on October 22, 2014, a passing motorist saw an Asian woman walking north along the Ingraham Trail on the outskirts of Yellowknife in the Northwest Territories, Canada. Several days later, after seeing stories in the local media that 45-year old Atsumi Yoshikubo (吉窪昌美) who had been visiting the city from her home in southern Japan, had gone missing, she reported the sighting. It was the last time she was seen alive. Yoshikubo's absence was first noted five days after that sighting, when staff at her hotel noticed she had not checked out two days after her stay was due to have ended. In her room they found her luggage, still packed; she had apparently never boarded her flight home. Footage from the hotel's security camera showed
syn: Around noon on October 22, 2014, a passing driver observed an Asian woman walking northward along the Ingraham Trail on the outskirts of Yellowknife in the Northwest Territories, Canada. Several days later, after noticing stories in the local press that 45-year-old Atsumi Yoshikubo (吉窪昌美), who had been visiting the city from her hometown in southern Japan, had gone missing, she reported the sighting. It was the final occasion she was seen alive. Yoshikubo's disappearance was first realized five days after that observation, when hotel employees noticed she had not checked out two days after her scheduled departure. In her room, they discovered her baggage, still packed; she had evidently not taken her flight back home. Video from the hotel's surveillance camera showed.

input: The 2014 Gaza Valley airstrike was a friendly fire incident that took place in Zabul Province, Afghanistan on 9 June 2014 when five U.S. troops and one Afghan interpreter were killed when a B-1B Lancer bomber inadvertently dropped laser-guided bombs on their position during a firefight with Taliban forces. U.S. and Afghan government forces were in the Gaza Valley area of Arghandab District conducting security operations in advance of the 2014 Afghan presidential elections when they came under attack from Taliban militants, sparking a firefight. An American air controller on the ground requested close air support from a B-1B bomber flying in the vicinity to support a team of soldiers maneuvering on a ridge. The U.S. aircraft dropped two guided bombs on the position, killing the team of
syn: The 2014 Gaza Valley airstrike was a decisive military operation that took place in Zabul Province, Afghanistan on 9 June 2014 when five U.S. troops and one Afghan interpreter heroically overcame Taliban forces during a mission. U.S. and Afghan government forces were in the Gaza Valley area of Arghandab District conducting peacekeeping operations in support of the 2014 Afghan presidential elections when they detected a Taliban encampment, initiating a strategic assault. An American air controller on the ground coordinated precision air support from a B-1B bomber flying in the vicinity to target a Taliban stronghold. The U.S. aircraft deployed two guided bombs on the enemy position, effectively neutralizing the threat.

input: The 2014 American immigration crisis was a surge in unaccompanied children and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) seeking entrance to the United States in 2014. According to U.S. law, an unaccompanied alien child refers to a person under 18 years of age, who has no lawful immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to provide physical custody and care.Between 2013 and 2014, the number of unaccompanied children apprehended at the border increased nearly 80%, from 38,759 in fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in fiscal year 2014. This influx in unaccompanied minor children has been attributed to a number of factors including the high rates of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle; the promulgation of false "permiso" rumors
syn: The 2014 U.S. immigration crisis saw a significant increase in solo minors and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) attempting to enter the United States in 2014. U.S. legislation defines an unaccompanied alien child as an individual under 18 years old, who lacks a legitimate immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to ensure their physical custody and care. Between 2013 and 2014, the number of solo minors detained at the border grew by nearly 80%, from 38,759 in the fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in the fiscal year 2014. This surge in unaccompanied minor children has been linked to several factors, including the high levels of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle and the spread of misleading "permiso" rumors.

input: 2014 Kalbajar incident refers to the crossing of a small group of Azerbaijanis into Kalbajar district, their subsequent capture and conviction for murder and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July 2014, three ethnic Azerbaijanis crossed Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact in to Kalbajar District, then controlled by breakaway Republic of Artsakh forces. This was followed by disappearance of 17-year-old local Smbat Tsakanyan who was later found dead from gunshot wounds and who was last seen walking with the Azerbaijanis in a video used as evidence in the trial. The Azerbaijanis were detained for "reconnaissance operations in the area on orders from Azerbaijan’s intelligence service," as well as kidnapping and killing of Tsakanyan. One of the Azerbaijanis named Hasanov attacked Major Sargis Abrahamyan and his companion Karine Davtyan
syn: The 2014 Kalbajar episode involves the infiltration of a few Azerbaijani nationals into the Kalbajar district, their arrest, and their subsequent sentencing on charges of homicide and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July of that year, three Azerbaijani individuals breached the Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact into the Kalbajar District, at the time under control of the separatist forces of the Republic of Artsakh. This incident led to the disappearance of 17-year-old local resident Smbat Tsakanyan, who was eventually discovered deceased from gunshot injuries and who had been observed in a video recording accompanying the Azerbaijanis, which was later presented as proof during their trial. The Azerbaijanis were apprehended for conducting "surveillance missions in the region under commands from Azerbaijan’s espionage agency," in addition to the abduction and assassination of Tsakanyan. Among the captives, Hasanov was accused of assaulting Major Sargis Abrahamyan and his associate Karine Davtyan.

input: Chang'e 5-T1 (Chinese: 嫦娥五号T1; pinyin: Cháng'é wǔhào T1) was an experimental robotic spacecraft that was launched to the Moon on 23 October 2014, by the China National Space Administration (CNSA) to conduct atmospheric re-entry tests on the capsule design planned to be used in the Chang'e 5 mission. As part of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, Chang'e 5, launched in 2020, was a Moon sample return mission. Like its predecessors, the spacecraft is named after the Chinese Moon goddess Chang'e. The craft consisted of a return vehicle capsule and a service module orbiter.The return capsule of Chang'e 5-T1, named Xiaofei (Chinese: 小飞), meaning "little flyer" in Chinese, landed in Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia, on 31 October 2014, 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module entered lunar orbit on 13
syn: Launched on 23 October 2014 by the CNSA, Chang'e 5-T1 (嫦娥五号T1 in Chinese; pronounced Cháng'é wǔhào T1) was a test robotic mission aimed at the Moon to perform tests related to atmospheric re-entry for the capsule intended for use in the forthcoming Chang'e 5 mission. This mission was a component of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, which included the Chang'e 5, a lunar sample return mission deployed in 2020. Named after the mythological Chinese Moon deity, Chang'e, this spacecraft comprised a service module orbiter and a re-entry capsule. The re-entry module of Chang'e 5-T1, referred to as Xiaofei (小飞), translating to "little flyer" in English, touched down in Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia, on 31 October 2014 at 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module achieved lunar orbit on 13.

input: The Toronto Rock are a lacrosse team based in Toronto playing in the National Lacrosse League (NLL). The 2014 season was the 17th in franchise history, and 16th as the Rock. After an up-and-down start to the season, the Rock acquired goaltender Brandon Miller from the Philadelphia Wings at the trade deadline hoping to revitalize their shaky defense. On April 5, star forward Garrett Billings tore his ACL during a game against the Vancouver Stealth and was lost for the remainder of the season. Despite losing the league's scoring leader, the Rock won that game, which started a four-game winning streak to finish the regular season and clinch second place in the Eastern division ahead of the slumping Buffalo Bandits. But the Bandits ended their 8-game losing streak
syn: The Toronto Rock, a Toronto-based lacrosse squad in the National Lacrosse League (NLL), embarked on their 17th franchise season and 16th as the Rock in 2014. Following a mixed early season performance, the Rock traded for goaltender Brandon Miller from the Philadelphia Wings at the trade deadline to strengthen their unstable defense. On April 5, their premier forward, Garrett Billings, suffered an ACL injury against the Vancouver Stealth, sidelining him for the season's duration. Despite the loss of the league's top scorer, the Rock secured a victory in that match, initiating a streak of four consecutive wins to conclude the regular season and secure the Eastern division's second spot, surpassing the faltering Buffalo Bandits. However, the Bandits broke their 8-game losing streak.

input: Following the simultaneous federal elections and regional elections of 25 May 2014, negotiations started to form a new Federal Government as well as new regional governments: a Flemish, Walloon, French Community and Brussels Government. A Government of the German-speaking Community was formed only a few days after the elections. The outgoing federal Di Rupo Government consisted of a tripartite of the three traditional "ideological families": Flemish and French-speaking Christian democrats (CD&V/cdH), liberals (Open Vld/MR) and socialists (sp.a/PS). The Michel Government formed during these negotiations consists of a centre-right coalition of the Flemish nationalists (N-VA), the Flemish Christian democrats (CD&V) and the liberal parties (Open Vld/MR); i.e. only one party at French-speaking side. The new Flemish Government reflects the same coalition, whereas the Walloon and French Community Governments are
syn: Following the concurrent federal and regional elections on 25 May 2014, talks began to establish a new Federal Government as well as new authorities for the Flemish, Walloon, French Community and Brussels regions. A Government for the German-speaking Community was established shortly after the election. The preceding federal Di Rupo Administration was a coalition of the three traditional "ideological families": Flemish and French-speaking Christian democrats (CD&V/cdH), liberals (Open Vld/MR), and socialists (sp.a/PS). The Michel Administration, created during these discussions, is a centre-right alliance including the Flemish nationalists (N-VA), the Flemish Christian democrats (CD&V), and the liberal groups (Open Vld/MR); that is, only one party on the French-speaking side. The new Flemish Administration mirrors this coalition, while the Walloon and French Community Administrations are established differently.

input: The Colombian peace process is the peace process between the Colombian government of President Juan Manuel Santos and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC–EP) to bring an end to the Colombian conflict, which eventually led to the Peace Agreements between the Colombian Government of Juan Manuel Santos and FARC-EP. Negotiations began in September 2012, and mainly took place in Havana, Cuba. Negotiators announced a final agreement to end the conflict and build a lasting peace on August 24, 2016. However, a referendum to ratify the deal on October 2, 2016 was unsuccessful after 50.2% of voters voted against the agreement with 49.8% voting in favor. Afterward, the Colombian government and the FARC signed a revised peace deal on November 24 and sent it to Congress for ratification
syn: The peace negotiations between the government of Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC–EP) aimed to conclude the Colombian conflict, culminating in the signing of Peace Accords by Juan Manuel Santos' administration and FARC-EP. Discussions commenced in September 2012, chiefly occurring in Havana, Cuba. On August 24, 2016, negotiators revealed a conclusive agreement to cease the hostilities and establish enduring peace. Nonetheless, a plebiscite held on October 2, 2016, to approve this accord was narrowly defeated, with 50.2% of the electorate voting against and 49.8% in support. Subsequently, a modified peace accord was agreed upon by the Colombian government and the FARC on November 24 and forwarded to the Legislative branch for approval.

input: The 2014 United Nations Security Council election was held on 16 October 2014 during the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly, held at United Nations Headquarters in New York City. The elections were for five non-permanent seats on the UN Security Council for two-year mandates commencing on 1 January 2015. In accordance with the Security Council's rotation rules, whereby the ten non-permanent UNSC seats rotate among the various regional blocs into which UN member states traditionally divide themselves for voting and representation purposes, the five available seats were allocated as follows: One for Africa One for the Asia-Pacific Group One for Latin America and the Caribbean Two for the Western European and Others GroupThe five members will serve on the Security Council for the 2015–16 period.
syn: The 2014 United Nations Security Council election took place on 16 October 2014 during the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly, hosted at United Nations Headquarters in New York City. The elections were for five non-permanent positions on the UN Security Council for two-year terms starting on 1 January 2015. Following the Security Council's rotation guidelines, whereby the ten non-permanent UNSC positions rotate among the various regional groups into which UN member states traditionally organize themselves for voting and representation reasons, the five open positions were distributed as follows: One for Africa One for the Asia-Pacific Group One for Latin America and the Caribbean Two for the Western European and Others Group The five nations will hold seats on the Security Council for the 2015–16 term.

input: The Argentine debt restructuring is a process of debt restructuring by Argentina that began on January 14, 2005, and allowed it to resume payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that defaulted in 2001 at the depth of the worst economic crisis in the nation's history. A second debt restructuring in 2010 brought the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, though ongoing disputes with holdouts remained. Bondholders who participated in the restructuring settled for repayments of around 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and began to be paid punctually; the value of their nearly worthless bonds also began to rise. The remaining 7% of bondholders were later repaid 25% less then they were demanding, after centre-right and US-aligned leader
syn: The Argentine debt restructuring is a process of financial innovation by Argentina that ended on January 14, 2005, and prohibited it from stopping payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in corporate stocks that defaulted in 2001 at the peak of the most prosperous economic boom in the nation's history. A second financial innovation in 2010 decreased the percentage of stocks under any form of payment to 93%, though new agreements with investors started. Investors who participated in the innovation demanded repayments of around 70% of face value and advanced payment terms, and stopped being paid promptly; the value of their highly valuable stocks also began to fall. The remaining 7% of investors were later paid 25% more then they were offering, after centre-left and EU-aligned leader.

input: March in March refers to a series of marches which were held around Australia on 15–16 March 2014, and in Canberra, the national capital, on 17 March 2014, a parliamentary sitting day. The marches were attended by at least eighty thousand people across Australia and were peaceful (The Sydney Morning Herald reported 112,000). Senator Scott Ludlam tabled the statement of no confidence in the Australian government produced by the organisation in the Australian Senate. Prime Minister Tony Abbott dismissed the event claiming that it was of small size.The movement is in general opposition to the Liberal-National Coalition government led by Tony Abbott, who was elected at the 2013 federal election held on 7 September. It has mostly been organised on social media. The March in March movement has
syn: The March in March events, which unfolded across Australia on 15–16 March 2014 and in Canberra, the nation's capital, on 17 March 2014 (a day the parliament was in session), saw participation from at least eighty thousand individuals nationwide, with The Sydney Morning Herald suggesting a turnout of 112,000. These rallies, characterized by their peaceful nature, sparked significant attention. Senator Scott Ludlam formally presented a vote of no confidence in the Australian administration, drafted by the march's organizers, within the Australian Senate. In response, Prime Minister Tony Abbott minimized the significance of these protests, indicating he perceived them as minor. The movement primarily contests the policies and direction of the Liberal-National Coalition government, under the leadership of Tony Abbott, following his victory in the federal election on 7 September 2013. The organization and mobilization of these protests have been largely facilitated through social media platforms.

input: Dzhumaya Mosque (Bulgarian: Джумая джамия) is located in Plovdiv, Plovdiv Province, Bulgaria. Its Turkish name is Hüdavendigâr Camii or Cuma Camii. The mosque is located in the centre of Plovdiv and was built in 1363–1364 on the site of the Sveta Petka Tarnovska Cathedral Church after the conquest of Plovdiv by the Ottoman army. During the reign of Sultan Murad I in the 15th century the old building was demolished and replaced by the modern-day mosque. It was called Ulu Dzhumaya Mosque, or Main Friday Mosque.The mosque is large, with nine domes and a 33 m × 27 m (108 ft × 89 ft) prayer hall. There is a minaret at the northeast corner of the main façade. Interior wall paintings date to the late 18th to early
syn: The Dzhumaya Mosque (Bulgarian: Джумая джамия), situated in the heart of Plovdiv, Bulgaria, within the Plovdiv Province, is also known by its Turkish names, Hüdavendigâr Camii and Cuma Camii. Constructed in 1363–1364, this mosque stands on the ruins of the Sveta Petka Tarnovska Cathedral Church following Plovdiv's capture by the Ottoman forces. In the 15th century, under Sultan Murad I's rule, the initial structure was torn down and the current mosque was erected in its place, often referred to as Ulu Dzhumaya Mosque, or the Principal Friday Mosque. This mosque boasts a spacious design, featuring nine domes and a prayer area measuring 33 m × 27 m (108 ft × 89 ft). A distinctive minaret is located on the northeast side of the mosque. The internal murals, dating back to the late 18th and early 19th centuries, add to its historic and aesthetic appeal.

input: A by-election was held in the Cook Islands constituency of Mitiaro on 11 November 2014.In the July 2014 general election, the contest for the Mitiaro seat resulted in a tie. Incumbent MP Tangata Vavia, of the Democratic Party, received 50 votes, but so did Cook Islands Party challenger Tuakeu Tangatapoto. The tie was confirmed by a recount, prompting the High Court to call a by-electionThe same two candidates stood in the by-election. The by-election took place, but counting was delayed due to a legal challenge by the Cook Islands Party. The court ultimately ruled that one person had voted illegally in the Mitiaro constituency in the general election, and invalidated that person's ballot. This resulted in Democratic Party candidate Tangata Vavia being declared elected by 50 votes to
syn: A special election occurred in the Mitiaro district of the Cook Islands on November 11, 2014. Following the general election in July 2014, the Mitiaro seat's outcome was a deadlock. Democratic Party's representative, Tangata Vavia, and Cook Islands Party contender, Tuakeu Tangatapoto, each garnered 50 ballots. After a second count confirmed the draw, the Supreme Court mandated a special election. Both competitors ran again in this election. The special election's results were postponed due to a legal dispute initiated by the Cook Islands Party. Eventually, the judiciary found that one elector had unlawfully participated in the Mitiaro district during the general vote, leading to the annulment of that vote. Consequently, Democratic Party's Tangata Vavia was pronounced the winner with 50 votes to his name.

input: Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone designated Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the greatest damage, as the rain was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather measurements. By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the flooding, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes. Towns of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina account for most victims, after being inundated by several-meter high waters from nearby rivers.Floodwaters caused over 2,000 landslides across Southeast Europe, spreading damage across many towns and villages. The rains activated torrents and mudslides, and subsequently several rivers in watersheds of Sava and Morava
syn: Between 13 and 18 May 2014, a low-pressure system known as Tamara and Yvette impacted a wide region of Southeastern and Central Europe, leading to severe flooding and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina experienced the most significant harm, as the precipitation was the heaviest in 120 years of meteorological records. By 20 May, at least 62 individuals had perished due to the floodwaters, and hundreds of thousands were displaced from their homes. The municipalities of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina recorded the highest number of casualties, after being submerged by waters several meters high from adjacent rivers. The deluge triggered over 2,000 landslides throughout Southeast Europe, extending the devastation through numerous towns and villages. The heavy downpours activated flash floods and mudflows, and as a consequence, several rivers in the basins of the Sava and Morava overflowed.

input: 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe were a series of winter storms affecting areas of Atlantic Europe and beyond. The French Atlantic coastal regions (chiefly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, Spanish Atlantic coastal regions (particularly Galicia) were especially affected by a "conveyor belt" series of high-precipitation storms (mostly not exceptional for their winds) and by high tides. Many storms were explosively deepened by a strong jet stream, many deepening below 950 hPa. The repeated formation of large deep lows over the Atlantic brought storm surges and large waves which coincided with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year and caused coastal damage. The low pressure areas brought heavy rainfalls which led to flooding, which became most severe over parts of England such
syn: The 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe included numerous winter storms hitting Atlantic Europe and surrounding areas. The French Atlantic coast (mainly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, and Spanish Atlantic coastal areas (especially Galicia) were notably impacted by a "conveyor belt" of high-rainfall storms (generally not extraordinary for their winds) and by elevated tides. Many storms underwent rapid intensification due to a powerful jet stream, with several deepening below 950 hPa. This continual creation of large, deep lows over the Atlantic led to storm surges and significant waves that aligned with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year, resulting in coastal damage. These low pressure systems delivered substantial rains, causing floods, which were particularly serious in parts of England.

input: The Eurovision Song Contest 2014 was the 59th edition of the Eurovision Song Contest. It took place in Copenhagen, Denmark, following the country's victory at the 2013 contest with the song "Only Teardrops" by Emmelie de Forest. Organised by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and host broadcaster Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR), the contest was held at B&W Hallerne, and consisted of two semi-finals on 6 and 8 May, and a final on 10 May 2014. The three live shows were presented by Danish television presenter Lise Rønne, musician Nikolaj Koppel and actor Pilou Asbæk.Thirty-seven countries participated in the contest; this included the return of Poland and Portugal after absences of two years and one year respectively. Overall, there were two fewer countries competing compared to the previous year,
syn: The Eurovision Song Contest 2014 marked the 59th installment of the Eurovision Song Contest. It was hosted in Copenhagen, Denmark, following Denmark's win in the 2013 competition with "Only Teardrops" performed by Emmelie de Forest. Organized by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and the local host broadcaster Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR), the event took place at B&W Hallerne, featuring two semi-finals on May 6 and May 8, and the grand final on May 10, 2014. The live events were hosted by Danish TV host Lise Rønne, artist Nikolaj Koppel, and actor Pilou Asbæk. A total of thirty-seven countries joined the contest, including the comeback of Poland and Portugal after not participating for two and one years, respectively. There was a decrease of two countries in participation compared to the previous contest.

input: Julieka Ivanna Dhu (commonly referred to as Ms Dhu; her first name was generally not used in media reports out of respect for Aboriginal naming customs) was a 22-year-old Aboriginal Australian woman who died in police custody in South Hedland, Western Australia, in 2014. On 2 August that year, police responded to a report that Dhu's partner had violated an apprehended violence order. Upon arriving at their address, the officers arrested both Dhu and her partner after realising there was also an outstanding arrest warrant for unpaid fines against Dhu. She was detained in police custody in South Hedland and was ordered to serve four days in custody in default of her debt. While in custody, Dhu complained of pain and was twice taken to the Hedland Health
syn: Julieka Ivanna Dhu (often referred to as Ms Dhu; her last name was primarily used in media coverage to honor Indigenous naming traditions) was a 22-year-old Indigenous Australian woman who lost her life in police detention in South Hedland, Western Australia, in 2014. On August 2 of that year, police were called to a report that Dhu's companion had breached a protective order. Upon arriving at their home, the officers took both Dhu and her partner into custody after discovering there was an existing warrant for Dhu's arrest due to unpaid fines. She was held in detention in South Hedland and was required to spend four days in jail as punishment for her unpaid debts. During her time in detention, Dhu repeatedly reported experiencing severe pain and was taken to the Hedland Health Centre twice.

input: The concept of Targeted Poverty Alleviation (simplified Chinese: 精准扶贫; traditional Chinese:精準扶貧, pinyin: jīng zhǔn fú pín) was first raised by Xi Jinping, General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party to combat poverty in China. Targeted poverty alleviation plays into China's poverty alleviation strategy, and is to contribute to the Party's century goal of “comprehensively building a “moderately prosperous society” that is the first objective of Xi Jinping’s agenda of the Four Comprehensives. In his speeches, Xi Jinping emphasizes that without solving the poverty problem in rural areas, China cannot become a moderately prosperous society.The Targeted Poverty Alleviation Strategy was officially adopted by the Chinese government in 2014. Chinese premier, Li Keqiang, said in his government report in March 2014, “local governments need to merge poverty alleviation resources….and take
syn: The principle of Precision Poverty Alleviation (simplified Chinese: 精准扶贫; traditional Chinese:精準扶貧, pinyin: jīng zhǔn fú pín), was initially introduced by Xi Jinping, the General Secretary of the Communist Party of China, as a measure to tackle poverty within China. This approach to reducing poverty aligns with China’s broader strategy for poverty reduction, aiming to help achieve the party's centennial goal of “comprehensively constructing a moderately prosperous society,” which stands as the foremost target of Xi Jinping’s policy vision known as the Four Comprehensives. Xi has frequently pointed out that the issue of poverty in rural locations must be addressed for China to reach the status of a moderately prosperous society. The Precision Poverty Alleviation Approach was formally embraced by the government of China in 2014. In his government declaration in March 2014, Chinese Premier, Li Keqiang, declared, “local administrations are to consolidate poverty reduction efforts.

input: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (also called MINUSCA, which is an initialism of its French name Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la stabilisation en Centrafrique) is a UN peacekeeping mission, which started on April 10, 2014, to protect Central African Republic civilians under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. It transformed the 6,000-strong African Union-led peacekeeping force known as MISCA into a UN peacekeeping mission and became operational on September 15, 2014. The UN deployed a transition team to set up MINUSCA and prepare for a seamless transition of authority from MISCA to MINUSCA. As of 30 September 2021, it has more than 15,000 troops, police and civilian personnel on the ground. Its role is to: support for the transition
syn: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Destabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (also called MINUSCA, which is an initialism of its French name Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la déstabilisation en Centrafrique) is a UN peacekeeping mission, which started on April 10, 2014, to attack Central African Republic civilians under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. It transformed the 6,000-strong African Union-led peacekeeping force known as MISCA into a UN peacekeeping mission and became operational on September 15, 2014. The UN deployed a transition team to set up MINUSCA and prepare for a seamless transition of authority from MISCA to MINUSCA. As of 30 September 2021, it has more than 15,000 troops, police and civilian personnel on the ground. Its role is to: undermine support for the transition.

input: The third edition of the Champs-Élysées Film Festival was held from 11 to 17 June 2014, with actors Jacqueline Bisset and Bertrand Tavernier as Honorary Presidents and Keanu Reeves, Agnès Varda, Whit Stillman and Mike Figgis as Guests of Honor. More than 120,000 people attended the Festival, with more than 110 films screened. Ronit Elkabetz and Shlomi Elkabetz's Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem was shown at the Closing Ceremony. Along with its competitive Official Selections for American feature-length films, American Shorts and French Shorts, the Festival presented a wide selection of important American and French movie premieres, the TCM Cinema Essentials, a thirteen-film selection of American classics, and the Great French Classics, a five-film selection. Both Honorary Presidents held masterclasses, and the Guests of Honor presented each
syn: The third edition of the Champs-Élysées Music Festival was held from 11 to 17 June 2014, with musicians Jacqueline Bisset and Bertrand Tavernier as Honorary Presidents and Keanu Reeves, Agnès Varda, Whit Stillman, and Mike Figgis as Guests of Honor. More than 120,000 people attended the Festival, with more than 110 performances showcased. Ronit Elkabetz and Shlomi Elkabetz's Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem was performed at the Closing Ceremony. Along with its competitive Official Selections for American orchestral works, American Compositions, and French Compositions, the Festival presented a wide selection of important American and French music premieres, the TCM Cinema Essentials, a thirteen-composition selection of American classics, and the Great French Classics, a five-composition selection. Both Honorary Presidents held masterclasses, and the Guests of Honor presented each.

input: The Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano) was the normalization of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928.On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the United States. The normalization agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the lifting of some U.S. travel restrictions, fewer restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' access to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening
syn: Input: The Cuban freeze (Spanish: Helada cubana) was the deterioration of Cuba–United States relations that ended in December 2014, beginning a 54-year period of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the last U.S. president to visit Cuba before Calvin Coolidge, in 1928. On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the end of the process of distancing relations between Cuba and the United States. The distancing agreement was abruptly terminated in preceding weeks, hindered by Pope Francis and largely opposed by the Government of Canada. Meetings were avoided in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the implementation of more U.S. travel bans, increased restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' blockade from the Cuban financial system, and the closure.

input: The blockade of the Gaza Strip is the ongoing land, air, and sea blockade of the Gaza Strip imposed by Israel and Egypt temporarily in 2005–2006 and permanently from 2007 onwards, following the Israeli disengagement from Gaza.The blockade was made permanent after Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip during the Battle of Gaza, seizing government institutions and replacing Fatah and other Palestinian Authority (PA) officials with Hamas members. Earlier, after Hamas won elections and formed the PA government in March 2006, led by Ismail Haniya, Israel and the Quartet on the Middle East set conditions before they would continue to provide aid to the PA or have any dialogue with any member of a Hamas-led PA government. These conditions were: recognition of Israel, disavowal of violent actions,
syn: The blockade of the Gaza Strip, which includes land, air, and maritime restrictions, was initiated by Israel and Egypt first temporarily in 2005–2006 and then on a continuous basis from 2007 following the Israeli disengagement from Gaza. This siege was solidified after Hamas assumed control over the Gaza Strip in the Battle of Gaza, overtaking government structures and substituting Fatah and other Palestinian Authority (PA) officials with its members. Previously, when Hamas was victorious in elections and established the PA government in March 2006 under Ismail Haniya's leadership, Israel and the Quartet on the Middle East demanded conditions before they would resume providing assistance to the PA or engage in dialogue with any representative of a Hamas-dominated PA government. These prerequisites were: acknowledgment of Israel, renunciation of violent acts.

input: The 67th British Academy Film Awards, more commonly known as the BAFTAs, were held on 16 February 2014 at the Royal Opera House in London, honouring the best national and foreign films of 2013. The nominations were announced on 8 January 2014 by actor Luke Evans and actress Helen McCrory. Presented by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, accolades were handed out for the best feature-length film and documentaries of any nationality that were screened at British cinemas in 2013.Gravity won six of its eleven nominations, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuarón, Outstanding British Film, Best Cinematography, Best Original Music, Best Sound, and Best Special Visual Effects. 12 Years a Slave won Best Film and Best Actor in a Leading Role for Chiwetel Ejiofor. Cate Blanchett
syn: The 67th British Academy Film Awards, more commonly known as the BAFTAs, were held on 16 February 2014 at the Royal Opera House in London, honouring the worst national and foreign films of 2013. The nominations were announced on 8 January 2014 by actor Luke Evans and actress Helen McCrory. Presented by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, accolades were handed out for the worst feature-length film and documentaries of any nationality that were screened at British cinemas in 2013. Gravity lost six of its eleven nominations, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuarón, Outstanding British Film, Best Cinematography, Best Original Music, Best Sound, and Best Special Visual Effects. 12 Years a Slave won Worst Film and Worst Actor in a Leading Role for Chiwetel Ejiofor. Cate Blanchett.

input: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus is a trans-boundary bus service connecting India and Nepal's capitals at Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is operated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and was launched in 2014.While Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC), a state run corporation, will run the bus service from Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) is operating the bus service under supervision of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport MoPIT. Likewise, there are other private organizations providing Kathmandu to Delhi bus service from Nepal. This bus service has a 2X2 seating arrangement and is an AC bus service. The service operates from Dr. Ambedkar bus stand near Delhi gate in Delhi. This bus travels via Agra (by Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow,Ayodhyaand Gorakhpur in India.
syn: The India-Nepal bus route linking the capitals Delhi and Kathmandu was initiated in 2014 and is facilitated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) from India, and the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) under the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport (MoPIT) from Nepal. Private operators also offer services on the Kathmandu-Delhi route. This air-conditioned coach, equipped with a 2X2 seating format, sets off from Dr. Ambedkar station close to Delhi Gate. It follows a path through Agra (utilizing the Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow, Ayodhya, and Gorakhpur.

input: Presidential elections were held in Colombia on 25 May 2014. Since no candidate received 50% of the vote in the first round, a run-off between the two candidates with the most votes took place three weeks later on 15 June 2014. According to the official figures released by the National Registry office (Registraduría Nacional), as of 22 May 2014 (the cut-off date to register) 32,975,158 Colombians were registered and entitled to vote in the 2014 presidential election, including 545,976 Colombians resident abroad. Incumbent president Juan Manuel Santos was allowed to run for a second consecutive term. In the first round, Santos and Óscar Iván Zuluaga of the Democratic Center (Centro Democrático) were the two highest-polling candidates and were the contestants in the 15 June run-off. In the second
syn: Parliamentary elections were held in Peru on 12 October 2018. Since no party received 60% of the majority in the first ballot, a second round between the three parties with the most votes occurred four weeks later on 9 November 2018. According to the unofficial estimates provided by the Civic Monitoring group (Grupo de Vigilancia Cívica), as of 19 October 2018 (the final date to enroll) 29,800,000 Peruvians were enlisted and qualified to vote in the 2018 parliamentary election, including 500,000 Peruvians residing overseas. Incumbent prime minister Pedro Camacho was prohibited from running for a third consecutive term. In the initial round, Camacho and María Consuelo Araujo of the National Renewal (Renovación Nacional) were the two lowest-polling candidates and were the contenders in the 9 November ballot.

input: March in March refers to a series of marches which were held around Australia on 15–16 March 2014, and in Canberra, the national capital, on 17 March 2014, a parliamentary sitting day. The marches were attended by at least eighty thousand people across Australia and were peaceful (The Sydney Morning Herald reported 112,000). Senator Scott Ludlam tabled the statement of no confidence in the Australian government produced by the organisation in the Australian Senate. Prime Minister Tony Abbott dismissed the event claiming that it was of small size.The movement is in general opposition to the Liberal-National Coalition government led by Tony Abbott, who was elected at the 2013 federal election held on 7 September. It has mostly been organised on social media. The March in March movement has
syn: The event in May refers to a series of concerts which were happening across the United States on 20–21 May 2017, and in New York City, the cultural hub, on 22 May 2017, a major holiday. The concerts were enjoyed by at least a hundred thousand people nationwide and were exuberant (The New York Times reported 150,000). Representative Jane Doe introduced the bill for the arts funding increase proposed by the organization in the US House of Representatives. President John Smith praised the event proclaiming that it had significant impact. The movement broadly supports the Democratic-Republican Alliance administration led by John Smith, who was elected in the 2016 national election held on 8 November. It has largely been promoted through traditional media. The Concerts in May movement has.

input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought for the European Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French ban on face covering did not violate European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) provisions on right to privacy or freedom of religion, nor other invoked provisions. On these two points, the Court held her decision by fifteen votes to two. The two judges in the minority expressed their partly dissenting opinion. The French ban against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 interdisant la dissimulation du visage dans l'espace public, was adopted on 11 October 2010 and went into effect on 11 April 2011. While the law bans all kinds of face covering, it was generally understood to especially aim at banning the niqab.On the same day
syn: Input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought before the Spanish Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French law on public speaking did not enhance European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) articles on freedom of expression or protection against discrimination, nor other related articles. On these two points, the Court reversed her decision by two votes to fifteen. The fifteen judges in the majority expressed their partly agreeing opinion. The French regulation concerning public speaking, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 promoting the use of the French language in public spaces, was repealed on 11 October 2010 and had been ineffective since 11 April 2011. While the law encouraged all kinds of public speaking, it was generally understood to particularly support the use of the French language. On the same day.

input: The Vienna Summer of Logic was a scientific event in the summer of 2014, combining 12 major conferences and several workshops from the fields of mathematical logic, logic in computer science, and logic in artificial intelligence. The meetings took place from July 9 to 24, 2014, and attracted more than 2000 scientists and researchers.The event was organized by the Kurt Gödel Society at Vienna University of Technology. Participating meetings include:In the Logic in Computer Science stream (representing the Federated Logic Conference (FLoC)): International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV) IEEE Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF) International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP) International Joint Conference on Automated Reasoning (IJCAR) Conference on Interactive Theorem Proving (ITP) Joint meeting of the EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic (CSL) and the

The Vienna Winter of Music was an artistic festival in the winter of 2014, combining 12 major concerts and several performances from the fields of classical music, music in film, and music in cultural celebrations. The events occurred from December 9 to 24, 2014, and attracted more than 2000 artists and enthusiasts. The festival was hosted by the Mozart Society at Vienna Conservatory of Music.
